prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We request a spectral resolution of ~0.2 km/s to spectrally resolve the CO and CS lines.

Our primary goal is to resolve for the first time the group II disks around Herbig stars. We request a spatial resolution of 0.14" translating into resolving disk radii larger than ~10 AU at a distance of 130 pc and larger than ~20 AU at 250 pc.

Our primary goal is to resolve for the first time the group II disks around Herbig stars. We request a spatial resolution of 0.14" translating into resolving disk radii larger than ~10 AU at a distance of 130 pc and larger than ~20 AU at 250 pc. In 30 minutes, we reach a continuum sensitivity (bandwidth of 1.875 GHz) of 0.1 mJy. The line sensitivity (resolution of 0.1 km/s) in the same time is 10 mJy. This is a factor of a few more sensitive than earlier ALMA observations of Herbig disks (e.g. de Gregorio-Monsalvo et al. 2013).
We request a spectral resolution of ~0.2 km/s to spectrally resolve the CO and CS lines.

We request a spatial resolution of 0.14" translating into resolving disk radii larger than ~10 AU at a distance of 130 pc and larger than ~20 AU at 250 pc. prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Protoplanetary disks around Herbig Ae stars show a dichotomy in their SEDs: in the mid-IR group I disks show a rise while group II disks are flat. Interestingly no group II disk has yet been detected in scattered light while several group I disks show inner cavities/gaps and profound deviations from axisymmetry (e.g. spiral arms, arcs). This substructure may reflect ongoing planet formation. If true, does the dichotomy in disk appearance suggest a dichotomy in the planetary system? Existing facilities lacked the sensitivity to measure sizes for group II disks, leaving us with 2 possibilities: (1) They are the small counterparts of group I disks, (2) they have similar sizes but lower surface brightness (low albedo or very flat structures) rendering them invisible in scattered light. We propose to measure in continuum and CO for the first time the dust and gas outer radii and the vertical scale height in a representative sample of group II disks. With a spatial resolution of 0.14" in band 7, we can measure disk sizes >10-20 AU out to 250 pc. Should the disks be larger, we expect to detect substructure comparable to the bean-like structures detected by ALMA in group I sources.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Kapteyn Astronomical Institute, University of Groningen
